title: Cat. 95  Fragment of a Wall Revetment, late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Fragment of a Wall Revetment  
Late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 3.2 × 5.2 × 0.8 cm (1 1/4 × 2 × 1/4 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1269

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Transparent yellowish-green, translucent deep-amethyst, and opaque white, yellow, and red glass. Wall revetment fragment fabricated by the mosaic glass technique, tooled, and polished on the face. The fragment preserves the left and top side of an inlay; the right and bottom edges are broken. In a deep-amethyst matrix is a mosaic pattern formed from segments of one cane: a stylized rosette with a central red dot and six surrounding yellowish-green dots all outlined in yellow and surrounded by a concentric ring of white dots.

The fragment is relatively thin in section. The face has been repolished but is still pitted; the edges and back are more heavily pitted with a dully iridescent weathering crust.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 95 Fragment of a Wall Revetment, late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.

</section>
